# Our study

- 30 Spanish monolinguals, 64 Mandarin Chinese speakers and 65 English speakers (L2 Spanish)

--

- Sociolinguistic background questionnaire
- Proficiency test
- Tasks:
  - Visual world paradigm
  - Melody anticipation task
  - Rhythmic synchronization task (Pagliarini, 2016)
  - Operation Span task (Unsworth et al., 2005)

# Summary

## English
- More proficiency > more prediction

---

# Summary

## English
- More proficiency > more prediction

## Mandarin Chinese
- More proficiency > more prediction
- Rhythm: better synchronization > faster prediction
- Pitch: better pitch processing > more prediction when +WM/-prof or -WM/+prof

---

# Summary

## English
- More proficiency > more prediction

## Mandarin Chinese
- More proficiency > more prediction
- Rhythm: better synchronization > faster prediction
- Pitch: better pitch processing > more prediction when +WM/-prof or -WM/+prof

## Spanish 
- Pitch: Better pitch processing > more prediction</br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Better pitch processing > more but later prediction in average and &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;+WM

---

# Discussion

- Improvement over proficiency: prediction as an optimal component



- Spanish and Chinese speakers influenced by pitch (and rhythm) abilities because of L1 experience

  - domain-general mechanisms activated in some conditions
  - domain-general and domain-specific abilities account for individual differences
  
---

# Conclusion

</br>
</br>
.center[
Linguistic prediction is likely underpinned by domain-general mechanisms.
]
